Title: Check your Council Tax balance and bills
Answer: You can view your Council Tax bill and balance by signing in to the Bradford Council online account.
Responses: You can view your Council Tax bill and balance by signing in to the Bradford Council online account.
Sign in to your Council Tax online account to view bills, balances, and instalments.
If you can’t access your account, you can request a copy bill or contact the Council Tax team.

Title: Apply for a Council Tax discount or exemption
Answer: You may be eligible for a discount or exemption (for example, single person discount or student exemption). Apply online and provide supporting evidence.
Responses: You may be eligible for a discount or exemption, such as single person discount or student exemption.
Apply online for Council Tax discounts/exemptions and provide supporting evidence where required.
Eligibility depends on who lives at the property—check the council guidance and apply online.

Title: Set up, change, or manage Council Tax direct debit
Answer: You can pay Council Tax by direct debit, online card payment, or other payment methods.
Responses: You can pay Council Tax by direct debit, online card payment, or other payment methods.
Direct debit lets you pay monthly—use the council payment service to set it up or change details.
If you’ve missed a payment, contact the billing team to discuss options and avoid recovery action.

Title: Tell the council you have moved home
Answer: If you move home, tell the council your old and new address and your move date so your Council Tax is updated.
Responses: If you move home, tell the council your old and new address and your move date so your Council Tax is updated.
Report your move as soon as possible to avoid incorrect bills for your old or new property.
If there are overlapping tenancy dates, contact Council Tax to confirm liability dates.

Title: Council Tax arrears, reminders, and enforcement
Answer: If you have missed payments, pay what you can quickly and contact the Council Tax team to discuss an arrangement.
Responses: If you’ve missed payments, pay what you can quickly and contact the Council Tax team to discuss an arrangement.
Missing instalments can lead to reminders and recovery action—act early to avoid escalation.
If you’re struggling financially, check if you qualify for Council Tax Support and ask about repayment plans.

Title: Find your bin collection day
Answer: Check your bin collection day using the council bin collection lookup by entering your postcode.
Responses: Check your bin collection day using the council bin collection lookup by entering your postcode.
The postcode lookup shows your next recycling and general waste collection dates.
If the lookup isn’t working, use the waste services page or contact the waste team for your schedule.

Title: Report a missed bin collection
Answer: If your bin was not collected, check it was out on time and placed correctly, then report a missed collection online.
Responses: If your bin was not collected, check it was out on time and placed correctly, then report a missed collection online.
Before reporting, make sure the bin wasn’t contaminated or overloaded and the lid was closed.
If the issue happens repeatedly, keep note of dates and contact the waste service team.

Title: Request a replacement bin
Answer: If your bin is damaged or missing, you can request a replacement online. You may need your address and the bin type.
Responses: If your bin is damaged or missing, you can request a replacement online.
You may need to provide your address and whether it’s a general waste or recycling bin.
If you can’t request online, contact the waste team for support.

Title: What goes in recycling and what does not
Answer: Recycling rules vary by area. Common items include paper, cardboard, and some plastics. Avoid contaminated items.
Responses: Recycling rules vary by area—common items include paper, cardboard, and some plastics.
Avoid putting contaminated items (food-soiled packaging) in recycling as it may not be accepted.
If you tell me the item (e.g., ‘pizza box’), I can guide what to do based on typical council rules.

Title: Book a bulky waste collection
Answer: You can book a bulky waste collection for large household items. Fees may apply depending on items and quantity.
Responses: You can book a bulky waste collection for large household items such as sofas or fridges.
Fees may apply depending on the number/type of items—check the booking details online.
Ensure items are accessible at the collection point to avoid missed pickup.

Title: Check if you might be eligible for benefits support
Answer: Eligibility depends on your circumstances (income, savings, household). Use guidance and calculators to understand options.
Responses: Eligibility depends on your circumstances such as income, savings, and household situation.
You can use benefits calculators and council guidance to check what support may be available.
If you share general information (no personal data), I can suggest which support pages to check next.

Title: Housing Benefit and Council Tax Support guidance
Answer: You may qualify for Housing Benefit (if eligible) and/or Council Tax Support. Apply online and provide proof of income, rent, and identity.
Responses: You may qualify for Housing Benefit (if eligible) and/or Council Tax Support depending on your circumstances.
Applications typically require proof of income, rent details, and identity documents.
If you are on Universal Credit, some support is handled differently—check council signposting first.

Title: Report a change in circumstances
Answer: Report changes (income, job, moving home, household changes) as soon as possible to avoid overpayments or delays.
Responses: You must report changes such as income, employment, moving home, or household changes as soon as possible.
Reporting quickly helps prevent overpayments and reduces delays in your claim.
If you receive Universal Credit, report changes in your UC account and also update the council where required.

Title: Universal Credit signposting
Answer: Universal Credit is managed by the DWP. Claims and payments are handled via your Universal Credit online account.
Responses: Universal Credit is managed by the DWP and is claimed through your Universal Credit online account.
The council can provide local support and signposting, but UC payments are handled by DWP.
If you need help while waiting for UC, check local hardship support options.

Title: Help with urgent financial hardship
Answer: If you are experiencing urgent hardship, check local welfare support, food support, and community services signposting.
Responses: If you are experiencing urgent hardship, you may be able to access local welfare or crisis support.
Support can include signposting to food support and community services depending on need.
If you are at immediate risk, contact emergency services first, then use council support guidance.

Title: Apply for a school place (admissions)
Answer: Apply for a school place via the council admissions portal. Check deadlines and provide required documents.
Responses: You can apply for a school place through the council admissions portal.
Check deadlines and provide required documents such as proof of address.
If applying outside normal intake, check in-year admissions guidance.

Title: Check school admissions deadlines
Answer: Admissions deadlines depend on primary, secondary, or in-year applications. Check the council key dates page.
Responses: Admissions deadlines depend on whether you are applying for primary, secondary, or in-year places.
The admissions pages list key dates, closing deadlines, and offer dates.
If you missed the deadline, you may still apply—check late application guidance.

Title: In-year school transfers
Answer: In-year transfers are available if you need to move schools during the year. Places depend on capacity and criteria.
Responses: If you need to move school during the year, apply for an in-year transfer through the council process.
Availability depends on school capacity and admissions criteria.
If your child has SEND needs, check SEND guidance alongside the transfer process.

Title: School transport guidance
Answer: School transport support depends on age, distance, and eligibility. Check the council guidance for criteria and applications.
Responses: School transport support depends on factors like distance, age, and eligibility criteria.
Check the council transport policy to see who qualifies and how to apply.
Some SEND cases may have different support routes—check the SEND transport guidance.

Title: Special Educational Needs and Disabilities (SEND) support
Answer: Bradford Council provides SEND guidance, including assessment routes and EHCP information.
Responses: Bradford Council provides SEND guidance for children and young people, including EHCP processes.
EHCP requests usually involve evidence of needs and school involvement—check the council steps and timelines.
If you already have school reports or support plans, these can support an assessment request.

Title: How much Council Tax do I need to pay?
Answer: How much you need to pay depends on your property band, any discounts/exemptions, and your payment plan. The quickest way is to check your latest Council Tax bill or sign in to the council’s online account to view your balance and instalments.
Responses: Your Council Tax amount depends on your property band and any discounts/exemptions. Check your latest bill or your online account to see the exact amount and instalments.
To see exactly how much you need to pay, view your latest Council Tax bill or sign in to your online account for your current balance and instalment dates.
The amount you pay depends on banding and discounts. The most accurate answer is in your Council Tax bill or online account balance.
